question:
The Permanent Settlement introduced by Cornwallis was NOT prevalent in which of the following regions of India?

SSC MTS 14/10/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Permanent Settlement was introduced by Lord Cornwallis in 1793.
  • It was implemented primarily in Bengal, Bihar, and parts of Odisha.
  • Under this system, Zamindars were recognized as landowners who paid a fixed revenue to the British.
  • The system was not extended to regions like Punjab, which came under British rule much later (after 1849).
  • Therefore, Punjab did NOT follow the Permanent Settlement system.

Additional Information:

  • In Punjab, the British implemented the Ryotwari and Mahalwari systems instead.
  • Ryotwari System: Introduced by Thomas Munro in Madras and Bombay presidencies; peasants paid revenue directly to the government.
  • Mahalwari System: Applied in parts of Central India, North-West Provinces, and Punjab; revenue collected from a group of villages (mahals).

question:
Who among the following devised the system of ‚ÄòSubsidiary Alliance‚Äô?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Subsidiary Alliance system was devised by Lord Wellesley, who served as the Governor-General of India from 1798 to 1805.
  • This policy aimed to bring Indian princely states under British control without direct annexation.
  • Under this system, Indian rulers were forced to accept British troops in their territory and pay for their maintenance.
  • They could not maintain their own armies or enter alliances with other powers without British permission.
  • The Nizam of Hyderabad was the first to accept the Subsidiary Alliance in 1798.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Canning was the Governor-General during the 1857 Revolt and became the first Viceroy of India.
  • Lord William Bentinck is remembered for social reforms like abolishing Sati.

question:
Which Governor-General of British India helped Raja Ram Mohan Roy legally abolish the Sati practice?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The practice of Sati (self-immolation of widows) was legally abolished in 1829.
  • The Governor-General of British India at that time was Lord William Bentinck.
  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy, a prominent social reformer, played a major role in creating public awareness against Sati.
  • With his support and advocacy, Lord William Bentinck passed the Bengal Sati Regulation, 1829, which declared Sati illegal and punishable.
  • This was a landmark step in British India's social reform movement.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ripon is known for introducing local self-government.
  • Lord Curzon is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Lord Cornwallis is remembered for the Permanent Settlement in Bengal (1793).

question:
The Doctrine of Lapse was an annexation policy devised by which of the following Governor-Generals of India?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Doctrine of Lapse was an annexation policy introduced by Lord Dalhousie, who was the Governor-General of India from 1848 to 1856.
  • According to this doctrine, if a ruler of a princely state died without a natural male heir, his kingdom would be annexed by the British.
  • The policy was used to annex several states including Satara (1848), Jhansi (1853), Nagpur (1854), and Awadh (1856).
  • This aggressive annexation strategy angered many Indian rulers, and was one of the factors leading to the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley introduced the Subsidiary Alliance.
  • Lord Mayo focused on administrative reforms and was assassinated in 1872.
  • Lord Canning was the first Viceroy of India and oversaw the end of the 1857 Revolt.

question:
Who asked James Rennel to prepare the map of Hindustan?

SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is Robert Clive.
  • ‚úÖ James Rennell was the first Surveyor General of Bengal.
  • üó∫Ô∏è He was tasked with mapping Hindustan (India) during British rule.
  • üìå It was Robert Clive who initially asked Rennell to prepare the map.
  • ü§ù Warren Hastings (first Governor-General of Bengal (1773‚Äì1785)) later supported and funded Rennell‚Äôs work, but did not commission it.
  • James Rennell, known as the ‚ÄúFather of Indian Geography‚Äù, was appointed as the Surveyor General of Bengal in 1767.
  • Rennell's surveys laid the foundation for modern cartography in India and helped the British in administrative planning and control.

  • Additional Information:

  • Robert Clive played a major role in establishing British rule after the Battle of Plassey (1757).
  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Ripon introduced Local Self-Government reforms in India.

question:
The Daroga system in 1792 was introduced by whom among the following Governor-Generals in India?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Daroga system was introduced in 1792 by Lord Cornwallis, the then Governor-General of India.
  • This system aimed to reform policing and law enforcement under British rule.
  • Under it, Darogas (police officers) were appointed to maintain law and order at the thana (police station) level.
  • The system was part of Cornwallis's broader judicial and administrative reforms, which also included the Cornwallis Code (1793).
  • It laid the foundation for the modern police structure in India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Minto is known for the Minto-Morley Reforms (1909).
  • Lord Mayo focused on infrastructure development and provincial finance decentralization.
  • Lord William Bentinck is noted for social reforms like abolishing Sati and promoting Western education.

question:
Who is called the father of Local Self-Government in India?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Lord Ripon is widely known as the "Father of Local Self-Government in India."
  • In 1882, he introduced a resolution that laid the foundation for local self-governance through municipalities and rural boards.
  • His reforms allowed elected Indian representatives to participate in local governance, thus promoting decentralization.
  • These measures aimed to encourage administrative training, political education, and greater public participation.
  • The system marked the beginning of democratic institutions at the local level in British India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis is known for judicial reforms and the Permanent Settlement.
  • Lord Wellesley introduced the Subsidiary Alliance.
  • Lord William Bentinck is remembered for abolishing Sati and introducing social reforms.

question:
Which of the following Governor-Generals of British India was in favour of free press and repealed the press regulations of 1823?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Lord Metcalfe is famously known as the ‚ÄúLiberator of the Indian Press.‚Äù
  • He repealed the Press Regulations of 1823 during his tenure as the Governor-General of India (1835‚Äì1836).
  • These regulations were introduced by John Adam (Acting Governor-General in 1823) to curb press freedom by requiring licenses for publication.
  • Lord Metcalfe, a firm believer in freedom of expression, removed these restrictions, enabling unlicensed printing and publication.
  • His liberal action laid the foundation for a freer press in colonial India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ellenborough is known for his military campaigns like the First Afghan War.
  • Lord Lytton imposed the Vernacular Press Act (1878), which curtailed press freedom.
  • Lord Ripon is noted for Local Self-Government reforms, not press freedom.

question:
In the context of British rule in India, who among the following Governor-Generals created a professional cadre of company servants making provisions for them for generous salaries?

Higher Secondary 21/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• The correct answer is Lord Cornwallis.
  • He is credited with creating a professional and efficient civil service under British rule.
  • During his tenure (1786‚Äì1793), he introduced the Cornwallis Code, which included reforms in administration, policing, and judiciary.
  • He emphasized honesty and efficiency among company officials and provided them with high salaries to discourage corruption.
  • This laid the foundation for the Indian Civil Services (ICS), later known as the Steel Frame of British India.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal and laid the groundwork for administrative control.
  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and railway/postal reforms.
  • Lord Mayo promoted infrastructure and provincial decentralization, but not civil service structuring.

question:
Whom did Lord Curzon entrust as architect for Victoria Memorial Hall?

Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• Lord Curzon, the then Viceroy of India, conceptualized the Victoria Memorial Hall in memory of Queen Victoria after her death in 1901.
  • He entrusted Sir William Emerson, a prominent British architect, as the chief architect of the monument.
  • The design of Victoria Memorial reflects a blend of British and Mughal architectural styles, often called Indo-Saracenic architecture.
  • Construction began in 1906 and was completed in 1921, located in Kolkata (then Calcutta).

Additional Information:

  • Robert Chisholm was known for early Indo-Saracenic architecture, mainly in South India.
  • Herbert Baker worked on buildings in New Delhi, including the Secretariat buildings.
  • Henry Irwin designed several buildings in Madras Presidency, including the Mysore Palace.

question:
Who among the following was the Viceroy of British India when the Shimla conference was held in 1945?

Higher Secondary 26/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• The Shimla Conference was held in June‚ÄìJuly 1945, during the tenure of Lord Wavell, the Viceroy of India at that time.
  • The conference was convened to discuss the Wavell Plan, which aimed to form a new Executive Council with Indian leaders.
  • Major political parties including the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League were invited.
  • The talks failed primarily due to disagreements between the Congress and the Muslim League over the issue of Muslim representation.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Linlithgow was Viceroy during the Second World War (1936‚Äì1943).
  • Lord Willingdon served from 1931 to 1936.
  • Lord Irwin was Viceroy during the Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931) and the Civil Disobedience Movement.

question:
English as the official language of India for higher education was incorporated in the resolution formulation by _______.

SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The correct answer should be Lord Macaulay, not Lord Wellesley.
  • Thomas Babington Macaulay played a key role in introducing English as the medium of instruction in higher education in India.
  • His famous Minute on Indian Education (1835) emphasized promoting European literature and science through the English language.
  • This led to the passing of Lord William Bentinck‚Äôs resolution in 1835, which formally adopted English for higher education in India.
  • Macaulay believed in creating a class of Indians who were ‚ÄúIndian in blood and color, but English in taste, opinions, morals, and intellect.‚Äù

Correct Answer: (c) Lord Macaulay

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley founded Fort William College in 1800 to train civil servants but did not introduce English as the official language.
  • Lord Dalhousie promoted Western education but after Macaulay‚Äôs reforms.
  • Lord Hastings focused on military and administrative consolidation, not education policy.

question:
The Vernacular Press Act was enacted during the regime of which viceroy of India?

SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The Vernacular Press Act was enacted in 1878 during the tenure of Lord Lytton, who served as the Viceroy of India from 1876 to 1880.
  • This act was introduced to curb the freedom of the Indian-language (vernacular) press, especially publications that criticized British policies.
  • It gave the government the power to confiscate printing presses and stop publication without trial.
  • The act was widely criticized as being repressive and discriminatory, as it did not apply to English-language newspapers.
  • It was eventually repealed by Lord Ripon in 1882.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and promoting infrastructure.
  • Lord Hastings focused on military expansion and administrative control.
  • Lord Ripon, known as a liberal viceroy, supported press freedom and local self-government.

question:
Who among the following signed a Tripartite treaty on behalf of the British Government to interfere in the affairs of Afghanistan?

SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Tripartite Treaty (1838) was signed between the British Government, Ranjit Singh (the Sikh ruler of Punjab), and Shah Shuja (exiled Afghan ruler).
  • The treaty aimed to place Shah Shuja on the throne of Afghanistan with British and Sikh support, replacing Dost Mohammad Khan.
  • It was signed on behalf of the British Government by Lord Auckland, the then Governor-General of India (1836‚Äì1842).
  • This intervention led to the First Anglo-Afghan War (1839‚Äì42), which ended in a major setback for the British.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mayo is known for infrastructure reforms and was assassinated in the Andaman Islands.
  • Lord Wellesley introduced the Subsidiary Alliance.
  • Lord Canning was the first Viceroy of India and led during the 1857 Revolt.

question:
Which of the following Commissions was appointed by Lord Curzon to enquire into the working of the police administration?

SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The Frazer Commission was appointed in 1902‚Äì03 by Lord Curzon, the then Viceroy of India, to examine and reform the police administration in British India.
  • The Commission was headed by Andrew Henderson Leith Frazer.
  • Its aim was to address issues such as corruption, inefficiency, and lack of training in the Indian police force.
  • The Commission recommended better training, pay scales, and organizational improvements for the police system.
  • This was a key step in the modernization of Indian policing under colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • Kitchener Commission dealt with military reforms under Lord Kitchener.
  • Hunter Commission (1882) was related to education reforms, appointed by Lord Ripon.
  • MacDonnell Commission focused on famine relief and food distribution policies.

question:
Who among the following has been accused of committing the judicial murder of Raja Nand Kumar?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Raja Nand Kumar, an Indian official, accused Warren Hastings, the then Governor-General of Bengal, of corruption in 1775.
  • Shortly afterward, Nand Kumar was arrested on charges of forgery and brought to trial.
  • He was tried by Sir Elijah Impey, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court at Calcutta, and was sentenced to death.
  • Nand Kumar was hanged in 1775, and this execution was widely condemned as a ‚Äújudicial murder‚Äù ‚Äî a misuse of judicial power to silence a political opponent.
  • Warren Hastings was accused of manipulating the judiciary to eliminate his critic.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley was known for the Subsidiary Alliance system.
  • Lord Dalhousie introduced the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Cornwallis focused on civil service and judicial reforms but was not involved in this case.

question:
______ announced the bifurcation of the British Indian Empire into a secular India and Islamic Pakistan.

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• The partition of British India into India and Pakistan was officially announced by Lord Louis Mountbatten, the last Viceroy of British India.
  • On 3rd June 1947, he announced the Mountbatten Plan, which outlined the process of bifurcating the British Indian Empire into two independent dominions ‚Äî a secular India and an Islamic Pakistan.
  • The plan was accepted by the Indian National Congress, the Muslim League, and the Sikh leaders.
  • This eventually led to the Indian Independence Act of 1947, passed by the British Parliament, and India and Pakistan became independent on 15th and 14th August 1947, respectively.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ripon is known for local self-government reforms.
  • Lord Dalhousie introduced the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Lord Curzon is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905), not the partition of India.

question:
Elphinstone was the Governor of which province of India during 1819‚Äì27?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer should be (d) Bombay.
  • Mountstuart Elphinstone served as the Governor of the Bombay Presidency from 1819 to 1827.
  • During his tenure, he carried out significant administrative and educational reforms.
  • He played a major role in the expansion of British control in western India after the Third Anglo-Maratha War.
  • Elphinstone also promoted Western education and is credited with laying the groundwork for institutions like Elphinstone College in Bombay (now Mumbai).

Correct Answer: (d) Bombay

Additional Information:

  • The North West Frontier Province was formally created much later, in 1901.
  • Madras and Bengal Presidencies were governed by other British officials during Elphinstone's Bombay tenure.

question:
The Viceroy who took keen interest in the restoration and protection of historical monuments was ________.

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is Lord Curzon, who served as the Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905.
  • He took a deep personal interest in the preservation and restoration of Indian historical monuments.
  • Under his leadership, the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act of 1904 was passed to protect and conserve important heritage structures.
  • He was instrumental in restoring monuments like the Taj Mahal, and took steps to safeguard temples, mosques, and forts.
  • His conservation efforts laid the foundation for organized archaeological work in India under the British.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ellenborough is remembered for the return of the gates of Somnath temple to India.
  • Lord Auckland is associated with the First Anglo-Afghan War.
  • Lord Lytton is known for the Vernacular Press Act (1878) and hosting the Delhi Durbar of 1877.

question:
The policy of dual system of government of Bengal was the brainchild of which Governor-General?

SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Dual System of Government in Bengal was introduced by Lord Robert Clive in 1765 after the Battle of Buxar (1764).
  • Under this system, the British East India Company received the Diwani rights (right to collect revenue) from the Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II.
  • The Nawab of Bengal retained the Nizamat functions (administration of law and order), while the Company controlled revenue and finance.
  • This allowed the Company to exercise real power without direct responsibility, creating a dual authority.
  • The system was highly exploitative and led to widespread corruption and economic hardship in Bengal. It was eventually abolished by Warren Hastings in 1772.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Hastings (1813‚Äì1823) is known for the Anglo-Maratha Wars and expanding British territory.
  • Lord Lytton is remembered for the Vernacular Press Act and the Delhi Durbar of 1877.
  • Lord Dalhousie implemented the Doctrine of Lapse and modernized infrastructure.

question:
Governor General Lord Dalhousie described the Kingdom of ______ "as a cherry that will drop into our mouth one day".

SSC MTS 08/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Lord Dalhousie, Governor-General of India (1848‚Äì1856), is known for his aggressive expansionist policies.
  • He described the Kingdom of Awadh (Oudh) as "a cherry that will drop into our mouth one day", indicating his belief that Awadh would eventually be annexed without much resistance.
  • In 1856, citing "misgovernance", Lord Dalhousie annexed Awadh into British territory under the pretext of providing better administration.
  • This annexation created deep resentment among soldiers and civilians, and was one of the causes leading to the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Ahom kingdom was annexed by the British earlier during the expansion in Assam.
  • Mysore had already seen conflict with the British during the Anglo-Mysore Wars.
  • The Maratha Empire was dismantled after the Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817‚Äì1818).

question:
"A History of British India" is a work published by ______.

SSC CGL 07/12/2022 (1st Shift)
solution:
• "A History of British India" is a famous historical work authored by James Mill, a Scottish economist and historian.
  • It was first published in 1817 and presents a detailed account of Indian history from the perspective of a British utilitarian philosopher.
  • Mill divided Indian history into three periods: Hindu, Muslim, and British, a classification that became influential in colonial historiography.
  • James Mill never visited India, yet his work significantly influenced British policies and attitudes toward Indian governance and culture.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Canning was the first Viceroy of India after the 1857 Revolt.
  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and modernization efforts.
  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal and focused on administrative and judicial reforms.

question:
In 1856, Governor-General _____ decided that Bahadur Shah Zafar would be the last Mughal king and after his death none of his descendants would be recognised as kings ‚Äì they would just be called princes.

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• In 1856, Lord Canning, the then Governor-General of India, made a significant political decision regarding the Mughal dynasty.
  • He declared that Bahadur Shah Zafar, the then reigning Mughal emperor, would be the last Mughal ruler.
  • After his death, his descendants would not be allowed to use the title of ‚Äúking‚Äù or reside in the Red Fort; they would be referred to only as princes.
  • This move deeply humiliated the Mughal family and contributed to the resentment that led to the Revolt of 1857, in which Bahadur Shah Zafar became a symbolic leader.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis is known for the Permanent Settlement and judicial reforms.
  • Lord Hastings expanded British territory and fought the Third Anglo-Maratha War.
  • Sir Thomas Munro implemented the Ryotwari system in Madras Presidency.

question:
Who among the following was the Viceroy of India during the formation of the Indian National Congress?

SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Indian National Congress (INC) was formed in December 1885 in Bombay.
  • At that time, the Viceroy of India was Lord Dufferin, who served from 1884 to 1888.
  • Although initially skeptical, Lord Dufferin supported the formation of the INC as a platform for Indians to express political opinions, believing it would help in channeling moderate Indian views.
  • The first session of the Congress was presided over by W.C. Bonnerjee, with 72 delegates in attendance.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Lytton (1876‚Äì1880) is known for the Vernacular Press Act and Delhi Durbar (1877).
  • Lord Ripon (1880‚Äì1884) promoted local self-government and repealed the Vernacular Press Act.
  • Lord Mayo (1869‚Äì1872) is remembered for infrastructure development and was assassinated in the Andaman Islands.

question:
Which of the following Viceroys of British India took the first step to separate provincial finance from central finance and introduced financial decentralisation in India in 1870?

Graduate Level 03/08/2022 (Shift - 3)
solution:
• The correct answer is Lord Mayo.
  • In 1870, Lord Mayo, the then Viceroy of India (1869‚Äì1872), took the first major step toward financial decentralisation in British India.
  • He introduced a system that separated provincial finances from central finances, allowing provinces to retain and manage revenue from certain sources (like excise, stamps, etc.).
  • This marked the beginning of devolution of financial powers to provinces and laid the groundwork for modern federal financial administration in India.
  • This reform is often referred to as the Mayo Resolution of 1870.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Chelmsford was Viceroy during the Montagu‚ÄìChelmsford Reforms (1919).
  • Lord Northbrook served from 1872 to 1876 but did not initiate financial decentralisation.
  • Lord Dufferin was Viceroy during the formation of the Indian National Congress (1885).

question:
Which of the following British officers issued the infamous ‚Äòcrawling order‚Äô whereby Indians had to crawl on all fours to pass an alley?

SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The infamous ‚Äúcrawling order‚Äù was issued by General Reginald Dyer in 1919, following the Jallianwala Bagh massacre in Amritsar.
  • After the massacre, General Dyer imposed humiliating measures on the local Indian population to ‚Äúteach them a lesson.‚Äù
  • One such order forced Indians to crawl on all fours if they wished to pass through the street (Kucha Kurrichhan) where Miss Marcella Sherwood, a British missionary, had been allegedly attacked.
  • This act was widely condemned and became a symbol of colonial brutality and racial discrimination.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal, not related to this event.
  • Lord Irwin was Viceroy during the time of the Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931).
  • Lord Curzon is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905) and heritage conservation policies.

question:
Which of the following Viceroys of India addressed the Bengal famine of 1943 by ordering the army to distribute relief supplies to the starving rural Bengalis?

SSC CGL 05/03/2020 (Evening)
solution:
• The Bengal Famine of 1943 was one of the worst famines in Indian history, leading to the deaths of an estimated 3 million people.
  • Although the famine began during the tenure of Lord Linlithgow (1936‚Äì1943), it was Lord Wavell, who became Viceroy of India in October 1943, who took active measures to address the crisis.
  • Lord Wavell ordered the British Indian Army to distribute relief supplies, including food and medical aid, to famine-stricken rural areas of Bengal.
  • He also prioritized improving food transportation and imports, and criticized the earlier inaction of the British administration.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mountbatten was Viceroy during the partition of India (1947).
  • Lord Willingdon (1931‚Äì1936) was known for suppressing civil disobedience movements.
  • Lord Linlithgow, under whose watch the famine began, has been criticized for inadequate response to early famine warnings.

question:
Consider the following statements-

Robert Clive was the first Governor General of Bengal.

2. William Bentinck was the first Governor General of India.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2007
solution:
• Statement 1: Robert Clive was the first Governor General of Bengal

    ‚ùåIncorrect ‚Äì Robert Clive was the Governor of Bengal, but not the first Governor-General.

    The title of Governor-General of Bengal was created under the Regulating Act of 1773, and the first person to hold that title was Warren Hastings.

  • Statement 2: William Bentinck was the first Governor General of India

    ‚úÖCorrect ‚Äì In 1833, the Charter Act designated the Governor-General of Bengal as the Governor-General of India.

    Lord William Bentinck became the first to hold the title of Governor-General of India with authority over all British territories in India.

Correct Answer: (b) Only 2

question:
Who was the first Governor General of India?

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 1997
solution:
• The correct answer is (c) Lord William Bentinck.
  • The Charter Act of 1833 created the title ‚ÄúGovernor-General of India‚Äù, replacing the earlier title ‚ÄúGovernor-General of Bengal‚Äù.
  • Lord William Bentinck, who had been the Governor-General of Bengal since 1828, became the first official Governor-General of India in 1833.
  • His jurisdiction was extended over all British territories in India, marking the beginning of centralized administration.

Additional Information:

  • Robert Clive was the Governor of Bengal, not a Governor-General.
  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal (appointed in 1773 under the Regulating Act).
  • Lord Dalhousie served later (1848‚Äì1856) and is known for the Doctrine of Lapse.

question:
Who was the first Governor General of India?

66th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re-Exam) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The title "Governor-General of India" was officially created under the Charter Act of 1833.
  • The first person to hold this title was Lord William Bentinck (not listed among the given options).
  • Hence, the correct answer is: (e) None of the above.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Lord Mayo: Viceroy of India (1869‚Äì1872), known for administrative and financial reforms.
  • Lord Lytton: Viceroy during the Delhi Durbar (1877) and Vernacular Press Act (1878).
  • Lord Canning: Last Governor-General and first Viceroy of India after 1857.
  • Lord Dufferin: Viceroy during the founding of the Indian National Congress (1885).

Correct Answer: (e) None of the above

question:
Consider the following events-

Clive's return to India

2. Treaty of Allahabad

3. Battle of Buxar

4. Warren Hastings becoming the Governor of India.

Select the correct sequence of the above events from the following code in the chronological order of their occurrence.

U.P. R.O./A.R.O. (Re-Exam) (Pre) 2016

Code :
solution:
• Clive‚Äôs return to India (1765): After the Battle of Plassey and initial administrative reforms, Robert Clive returned to India in 1765 as Governor of Bengal.
  • Battle of Buxar (1764): This decisive battle between the British and the combined forces of Mir Qasim, Shuja-ud-Daula, and the Mughal emperor Shah Alam II occurred before Clive's return.
  • Treaty of Allahabad (1765): Signed after the Battle of Buxar by Clive with Shah Alam II and Shuja-ud-Daula, granting the British Diwani rights of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
  • Warren Hastings becomes Governor (1772): He became the Governor of Bengal in 1772 and later the first Governor-General of India in 1774.

Thus, the correct chronological sequence is:

3 (Battle of Buxar), 1 (Clive‚Äôs Return), 2 (Treaty of Allahabad), 4 (Warren Hastings as Governor)

Correct Answer: b

question:
Which of the following statements is not correct?

U.P. P.S.C. (GIC) 2010
option_1: The foundation of public administration was laid firmly by Warren Hastings on which the superstructure was laid by Cornwallis.
option_2: Clive was credited with carrying out the civil and military reforms of the East India Company.
option_3: Lord William Bentinck was one of the greatest British rulers; as he consolidated the British Empire in India.
option_4: Lord Dalhousie added rich areas to the British Empire on the basis of the principle of Dhyuti.
solution:
• The statement in option (a) is correct. Warren Hastings established the foundation of public administration, which was later organized into a structured system by Lord Cornwallis, often called the "Father of Indian Civil Services".
  • Option (b) is also correct. Robert Clive is credited with laying down the civil and military administrative structure of the East India Company after the Battle of Plassey (1757).
  • Option (c) is not correct. While Lord William Bentinck introduced several social and educational reforms (e.g., abolition of Sati), he did not consolidate the British Empire. That phase came more prominently during Lord Dalhousie‚Äôs tenure.
  • Option (d) is mostly correct in intent but contains a factual error: The term ‚ÄúDhyuti‚Äù is incorrect and meaningless in this context. It should have been ‚ÄúDoctrine of Lapse‚Äù, which Lord Dalhousie used to annex princely states.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Bentinck‚Äôs major reforms included the abolition of Sati (1829), promotion of English education, and suppression of thugs.
  • Lord Dalhousie annexed several states like Jhansi, Satara, and Nagpur using the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • Robert Clive laid the foundation for Company rule in Bengal, which later expanded into all of India.

question:
Who was the founder of the British Empire in India?

66th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re-Exam) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Lord Clive, also known as Robert Clive, is considered the founder of the British Empire in India.
  • He played a key role in establishing British military and political dominance in India.
  • His victory in the Battle of Plassey (1757) laid the foundation for British control in Bengal.
  • In 1765, he secured Diwani rights (revenue collection) of Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa through the Treaty of Allahabad.
  • These actions helped transform the East India Company from a trading entity into a territorial power.

Additional Information:

  • C. Sleeman was known for eliminating the Thuggee cult in India.
  • Lord Minto (I) was involved with the Charter Act of 1813, while Lord Minto II is linked to the Minto-Morley Reforms (1909).
  • Lord Mayo served as Viceroy of India (1869‚Äì1872) and initiated financial decentralization.

question:
Who led the 'Banaras revolt' against the British?

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Pre) 2021
option_4: Raja Mahip Narayan Singh
solution:
• The Banaras Revolt was led by Raja Chet Singh in 1781 against the British East India Company.
  • He was the ruler of Banaras (Varanasi) and had been appointed by the British as a vassal ruler.
  • The revolt occurred when Warren Hastings, the Governor-General, demanded additional revenue and military assistance, which Chet Singh resisted.
  • When he refused, the British tried to arrest him, but his supporters rebelled, and British forces suffered losses.
  • Although the revolt was suppressed, it exposed the growing resentment against British interference.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Mahip Narayan Singh succeeded Chet Singh after the revolt but ruled under direct British supervision.
  • Shuja-ud-Daula and Asaf-ud-Daula were Nawabs of Awadh and not directly involved in the Banaras uprising.

question:
Who was the Governor General of Bengal at the time of establishment of the Asiatic Society in Calcutta?

U.P.P.S.C. (R.I.) 2014
solution:
• The Asiatic Society was established in 1784 in Calcutta (now Kolkata).
  • It was founded by Sir William Jones, a British judge and orientalist, to promote Oriental studies.
  • At that time, the Governor General of Bengal was Lord Warren Hastings.
  • Warren Hastings supported the initiative, as he had a deep interest in Indian culture and legal systems.
  • The society became a center for research in history, linguistics, literature, and archaeology related to India and Asia.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis became Governor General later in 1786 and is known for the Permanent Settlement.
  • Lord Wellesley (1798‚Äì1805) was known for expansionist policies including subsidiary alliance.
  • Lord Bentinck (1828‚Äì1835) is noted for social reforms like the abolition of Sati.

question:
The policy of 'Security Cell' is related to-

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2006
solution:
• The 'Security Cell' policy is associated with Warren Hastings, the first Governor-General of Bengal.
  • This policy referred to surveillance and intelligence mechanisms set up to monitor the activities of Indian rulers and potential threats to British authority.
  • Hastings emphasized internal security and political control, especially during the early phase of British rule in India.
  • He used such measures to suppress resistance, prevent conspiracies, and maintain British dominance.
  • It was a precautionary administrative approach reflecting Hastings‚Äô concern over the stability of the British East India Company‚Äôs governance.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and railway/telegraph development.
  • Henry Lawrence was a British administrator involved in the Punjab and Lucknow affairs.
  • Lord Hastings is associated with the Anglo-Maratha Wars and subsidiary alliance expansion.

question:
'Ring Fence' policy is related to which of the following?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• The 'Ring Fence Policy' is associated with Warren Hastings, the first Governor-General of Bengal.
  • This policy was implemented in the late 18th century to safeguard British interests in India by maintaining a buffer zone.
  • The idea was to protect British territories by forming alliances with neighboring Indian states to act as a ‚Äúfence‚Äù against external threats, especially Marathas and Hyder Ali of Mysore.
  • Under this policy, the British provided support (money or troops) to allied Indian rulers without direct annexation.
  • It marked the beginning of British diplomatic and military interference in Indian political affairs.

Additional Information:

  • Henry Lawrence was involved in British administration during the First War of Independence (1857).
  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and infrastructural reforms.
  • Lord Clive laid the foundation of British political rule in India after the Battle of Plassey (1757).

question:
Who among the following ended the Dual Government system in Bengal?

47th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2005

41st B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1996
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• The Dual Government system in Bengal was introduced by Robert Clive in 1765, after the Treaty of Allahabad.
  • Under this system, the British (East India Company) had the Diwani rights (revenue collection), while the Nawab retained Nizamat rights (administration and justice), creating a dual structure of power.
  • This system led to administrative inefficiency, corruption, and suffering of the local population.
  • In 1772, Warren Hastings, the first Governor-General of Bengal, abolished the Dual Government system.
  • He brought administration and revenue collection under direct Company control, centralizing power for effective governance.

Additional Information:

  • Robert Clive implemented the dual system but did not end it.
  • Lord Cornwallis came later (1786‚Äì1793) and is known for judicial and administrative reforms, including the Permanent Settlement of Bengal (1793).

question:
By whom was the system of dual governance implemented in Bengal?

66th B.P.S.C (Pre) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Dual Government system in Bengal was implemented by Robert Clive in 1765 after the Battle of Buxar (1764) and the Treaty of Allahabad.
  • Under this system, the British East India Company obtained Diwani rights (revenue collection), while the Nawab of Bengal retained Nizamat rights (law and order, administration).
  • This arrangement allowed the British to control revenue without bearing administrative responsibilities, using the Nawab as a puppet.
  • The system led to administrative inefficiency, corruption, and economic hardship among the people.
  • It continued until Warren Hastings abolished it in 1772, bringing administration and revenue under direct Company control.

Additional Information:

  • William Bentinck is known for social reforms like the abolition of Sati.
  • Lord Curzon served as Viceroy of India (1899‚Äì1905) and is known for the partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Warren Hastings ended the Dual Government but did not implement it.

question:
Which Governor General was subjected to impeachment case?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1992
solution:
• Warren Hastings, the first Governor-General of Bengal (1773‚Äì1785), was the only Governor-General subjected to an impeachment trial in Britain.
  • After returning to England in 1785, he was impeached in 1787 by the British Parliament for alleged misgovernance, corruption, and oppression in India.
  • The trial was led by Edmund Burke, with support from Charles James Fox and Richard Sheridan.
  • The charges included abuse of power, especially in dealings with figures like Raja Chet Singh and Begums of Oudh.
  • After a lengthy trial that lasted seven years (1788‚Äì1795), Hastings was acquitted of all charges.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Clive was accused of corruption but never formally impeached.
  • Lord Cornwallis is known for administrative reforms and the Permanent Settlement.
  • Lord Wellesley expanded British control via the subsidiary alliance but faced no impeachment.

question:
Who among the following was tried for impeachment in the British Parliament?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2006

U.P. P.S.C. (GIC) 2010
solution:
• Warren Hastings, the first Governor-General of Bengal (1773‚Äì1785), was the only high-ranking British official in India to be tried for impeachment in the British Parliament.
  • He was impeached in 1787 on charges of corruption, misuse of power, and oppressive administration during his tenure in India.
  • The trial was spearheaded by Edmund Burke, with support from Charles James Fox and Richard Sheridan.
  • Key accusations involved his actions against Raja Chet Singh, Begums of Oudh, and policies that allegedly exploited Indians.
  • The trial lasted nearly 7 years (1788‚Äì1795), and Hastings was ultimately acquitted.

Additional Information:

  • Sir John Shore succeeded Cornwallis but was not involved in any impeachment.
  • Lord Clive faced criticism and a parliamentary inquiry but was never formally impeached.
  • General Dyer, responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh massacre (1919), was censured but not tried in Parliament.

question:
Vellore rebellion took place during the tenure of which Governor General?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
solution:
• The Vellore Rebellion occurred in 1806 and is considered the first major military uprising against British rule in India, even before the Revolt of 1857.
  • It took place at the Vellore Fort (Tamil Nadu) and involved Indian sepoys who revolted against British military regulations, particularly those affecting religious customs.
  • The revolt was triggered by restrictions on wearing religious marks and forced dress codes, perceived as an attack on Hindu and Muslim traditions.
  • The uprising was short-lived but violent, leading to the deaths of around 200 British soldiers before being suppressed.
  • At that time, the Governor-General of India was Sir George Barlow (1805‚Äì1807).

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley served before Barlow (1798‚Äì1805) and was known for the subsidiary alliance system.
  • Lord Minto succeeded Barlow in 1807.
  • Lord Cornwallis served two terms but was not Governor-General during the Vellore rebellion.

question:
Who established the judicial organization in India?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1991
solution:
• The judicial organization in British India was established by Lord Cornwallis, who served as the Governor-General of Bengal from 1786 to 1793.
  • He is known as the ‚ÄúFather of the Indian Judicial System‚Äù due to his extensive reforms in the judiciary and administration.
  • Cornwallis introduced the Cornwallis Code (1793), which laid the foundation for a structured and impartial judicial system.
  • Key features included:
    • Separation of executive and judicial powers
    • Establishment of civil and criminal courts
    • Introduction of European judges in higher courts
    • Promotion of rule of law and equality before law (though limited in scope)

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mayo was Viceroy (1869‚Äì1872) and focused on financial decentralization and education.
  • Lord Attlee was British Prime Minister when India gained independence (1947).
  • Lord Curzon is known for the partition of Bengal (1905) and educational reforms.

question:
Which of the following Governor Generals created the Covenanted Civil Service of India, which later came to be known as the Indian Civil Service?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• The Covenanted Civil Service (CCS) of India, which later evolved into the Indian Civil Service (ICS), was created by Lord Cornwallis.
  • He is known as the ‚ÄúFather of Civil Services in India‚Äù.
  • During his tenure as Governor-General of Bengal (1786‚Äì1793), Cornwallis restructured the administrative system to ensure efficiency, honesty, and discipline.
  • He introduced strict rules, high salaries, and merit-based appointments to reduce corruption and favoritism.
  • Only British citizens (from covenanted class) were allowed to enter the service initially through nomination and later through competitive exams.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings laid the foundation of administrative structure but did not formalize civil services.
  • Lord Wellesley established the Fort William College for training civil servants, but the service itself was Cornwallis's initiative.
  • Lord William Bentinck introduced social reforms but was not the founder of the civil service.

question:
The Indian Civil Service was introduced in-

U.P. P.C.S. (Spl.) (Mains) 2004
option_1: During the reign of Bentinck
option_2: During the reign of Cornwallis
option_3: During the reign of Curzon
option_4: During the reign of Dalhousie
solution:
• The Indian Civil Service (ICS), originally known as the Covenanted Civil Service, was introduced during the tenure of Lord Cornwallis.
  • Cornwallis served as the Governor-General of Bengal from 1786 to 1793.
  • He established a structured, efficient, and honest administrative system by creating a professional civil service.
  • To ensure integrity, he implemented:
    • High salaries to prevent corruption
    • Strict rules of conduct
    • Merit-based appointments, initially through nominations and later through competitive exams.
  • Because of these reforms, Cornwallis is called the ‚ÄúFather of the Indian Civil Service.‚Äù

Additional Information:

  • Lord Bentinck is known for social reforms like the abolition of Sati.
  • Lord Curzon is associated with the partition of Bengal (1905) and educational reforms.
  • Lord Dalhousie implemented the Doctrine of Lapse and promoted railway and postal development.

question:
Who was often called the local representative of the "Company Bahadur ki Shan‚Äôo Shokat" in the latter half of the 18th century?

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Pre) 2021
solution:
• In the latter half of the 18th century, the term ‚ÄúCompany Bahadur ki Shan‚Äôo Shokat‚Äù referred to the prestige and grandeur of the East India Company.
  • The Inspector (Daroga) was often seen as the local representative of this power, symbolizing the Company‚Äôs authority at the ground level.
  • The Inspector enforced law and order, collected intelligence, and represented colonial control in rural and urban areas.
  • He became a visible face of British dominance, often feared and respected by the common people.
  • This perception led to the Inspector being described as a symbol of the Company‚Äôs might and arrogance.

Additional Information:

  • Police Officer is a more modern term; the structure in the 18th century revolved around Darogas and Kotwals.
  • Staff is a vague term and not a direct representative of Company authority.
  • Landlords (Zamindars) were local powerholders but acted for revenue purposes, not administrative policing.

question:
Where is the tomb of Lord Cornwallis located?

U.P.P.C.S (Mains) 2011
solution:
• The tomb of Lord Cornwallis is located in Ghazipur, in the present-day state of Uttar Pradesh, India.
  • Lord Cornwallis served as the Governor-General of India during two terms (1786‚Äì1793 and briefly in 1805).
  • He is known for major administrative reforms, including the Permanent Settlement of Bengal and the foundation of the Indian Civil Service.
  • During his second term in 1805, Cornwallis died in Ghazipur while traveling to address the political situation in India.
  • His tomb, a simple yet elegant structure, was built by the British and still stands as a historical monument maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India.

Additional Information:

  • Ballia, Varanasi, and Gorakhpur are nearby districts in eastern Uttar Pradesh, but they are not associated with Cornwallis‚Äôs death or burial site.
  • Ghazipur lies on the banks of the River Ganges, and the tomb is situated within the Cornwallis Memorial campus near the city.

question:
Which one of the following statements does not apply to the Subsidiary Treaty System introduced by Lord Wellesley?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2018
option_1: To maintain a large army at the expense of others
option_2: To keep India safe from Napoleon's threat
option_3: To arrange a fixed income for the Company
option_4: To establish British supremacy over the Indian princely states
solution:
• The Subsidiary Alliance System was introduced by Lord Wellesley in the late 18th century (specifically from 1798 onward).
  • Its primary objective was to establish British supremacy over Indian princely states without direct annexation.
  • Under this system:
    • Indian rulers had to maintain British troops in their territory at their own expense.
    • They were forbidden from forming alliances with other powers without British approval.
    • A British Resident was stationed at the ruler‚Äôs court to monitor and control state affairs.
    • It was also used as a defensive strategy to counter threats from powers like Napoleon, especially during his Egyptian campaigns.
  • However, the system was not designed to ensure a fixed income for the Company. Its focus was strategic and political dominance, not direct revenue.

Correct Answer: (c) To arrange a fixed income for the Company

Additional Information:

  • Major Indian states like Hyderabad, Awadh, Mysore, and Gwalior came under this alliance system.
  • The system helped the British avoid war and still gain effective control over Indian rulers.

question:
The first Maratha chieftain to accept the subsidiary treaty of Lord Wellesley was-

41st B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1996
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• The first Maratha chieftain to accept Lord Wellesley‚Äôs Subsidiary Alliance was Peshwa Baji Rao II.
  • After being defeated by Yashwantrao Holkar in the Battle of Poona (1802), Baji Rao II sought British help to regain his position.
  • He signed the Treaty of Bassein on 31 December 1802, which was a classic subsidiary alliance.
  • As per the treaty:
    • The Peshwa agreed to maintain British troops at his own expense.
    • He surrendered control over foreign affairs and allowed a British Resident at his court.
  • This treaty marked the beginning of British interference in Maratha affairs, leading to the Second Anglo-Maratha War (1803‚Äì1805).

Correct Answer: (a) Peshwa Baji Rao II

Additional Information:

  • Raghuji Bhosale (Nagpur) and Daulatrao Scindia (Gwalior) later accepted similar treaties but only after being defeated in the Second Anglo-Maratha War.
  • The Treaty of Bassein was strongly opposed by other Maratha leaders, as it signified a loss of sovereignty.

question:
Between whom was the 'Treaty of Bassein' of 1802 signed?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2012
option_1: British and Bajirao I
option_2: British and Bajirao II
option_3: French and Bajirao I
option_4: Dutch and Bajirao II
solution:
• The Treaty of Bassein was signed in 1802 between the British East India Company and Peshwa Baji Rao II.
  • After being defeated by Yashwantrao Holkar, Baji Rao II sought British support to regain his position.
  • The treaty was signed on 31 December 1802 at Bassein (Vasai), near modern-day Mumbai.
  • As per the treaty:
    • Baji Rao II had to maintain a British subsidiary force at his own expense.
    • He surrendered control over foreign relations and alliances.
    • A British Resident was stationed permanently at his court.
  • This treaty made the Peshwa a dependent ally, triggering opposition from other Maratha chiefs and resulting in the Second Anglo-Maratha War (1803‚Äì1805).

Additional Information:

  • The Treaty of Bassein is considered a turning point in Maratha-British relations.
  • It gave the British a strategic foothold in western India.
  • Other Maratha leaders like Scindia and Bhonsle opposed it and were eventually defeated by the British.
